image.altText: Hayley Raso smiles and is hugged by her teammates

image.altText: A group of soccer players wearing yellow and green hug each other while celebrating a win

items.synopsis: Having grappled with their heavyweight status, the Matildas defeated Denmark in the way only a serious World Cup contender should.

title.children: Are the Matildas coming of age after mature World Cup win over Denmark?

image.altText: Memorial to five boys killed in Russell Island house fire with ball, teddybears resting against fence that has a drawing on it

items.synopsis: A Russell Island soccer club will observe a minute's silence to honour the memory of five children and their father, who died tragically in a house fire over the weekend.

title.children: 'It's just unbelievable': Shocked community grieves friends killed in devastating house fire

image.altText: A badly crashed car at the bottom of some bushland.

items.synopsis: A 17-year-old schoolboy has been charged over a car crash in Brisbane's north-west last month which killed one of his friends and injured another.

title.children: Teen charged with dangerous driving after fatal crash kills friend

image.altText: Men arrested, children removed in global child sexual abuse investigation

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police reveals details of the joint FBI operation targeting child abuse material on the dark web.

image.altText: People silhouetted against a white and blue KPMG logo.

items.synopsis: Newly compiled data reveals Defence has spent nearly $4 billion on large consulting firms over the past decade, more than all other Australian government departments combined.

title.children: 'Something's rotten': New analysis reveals $4 billion Defence department spend on consultancy firms

image.altText: A composite image of Christopher Pyne and Joe Hockey

items.synopsis: In Australia there has long been disquiet about the revolving door between high political office and big business. Look at the defence industry, for example, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A new generation of former MPs has turned to big business

image.altText: A large four wheel drive rams a fence on an oval

items.synopsis: Police will send warnings about unfolding, high-risk situations to mobile phones to help keep residents safe and aware and avoid the spread of misinformation.

title.children: Text alerts warn drivers of stolen car rampages in outback hub of Mount Isa

image.altText: A woman in a sari stands in front of shelves lined with black pots

items.synopsis: Gautam Adani won the tender to transform one of the world's largest slums into a thriving, modern metropolis. But those in Dharavi fear the development could push them out and turn it into a playground for the rich.

title.children: India's rich and famous live on the edge of a Mumbai slum. Now the land has become highly coveted

image.altText: Bec Nicoll and Sarah Thomson crouch with their two dogs, on the ground of their wrecked house.

items.synopsis: Australians are facing a "broken" insurance system as the risk of bushfires, floods and cyclones increases with climate change, a new report out today says.

title.children: Bec and Sarah didn't want to repair a property that could just flood again. Turns out, their insurance claim wasn't that simple

image.altText: The icon for the video sharing TikTok app is seen on a smartphone.

items.synopsis: TikTok is starting a massive recruitment drive for tech workers in Sydney in a move one expert says is linked to concerns over its links with China.

title.children: 'Reading the political room': TikTok starting up Australian research and development lab following security risk concerns

image.altText: A streak of light in the sky at night.

items.synopsis: Dozens of people reported seeing what looked like a flaming meteor in the night sky over Melbourne last night, but was probably space junk re-entering the atmosphere.

title.children: Dozens of people report flaming 'meteor' over Melbourne's night sky

image.altText: A close-up photo of two mushrooms being held by a research wearing blue rubber gloves.

items.synopsis: As a small town in Victoria's east mourns the loss of three well-known community members who are believed to have eaten poisonous mushrooms, health officials are warning people to avoid foraging for fungi.

title.children: The death cap mushroom is one of the deadliest in Victoria. Here's what we know about it

items.synopsis: In the 1967 referendum on Indigenous rights, the NSW electorate of Cowper recorded one of the highest "no" votes. Now, Gumbaynggirr elders are reflecting on past lessons as they prepare for the second Indigenous referendum in their lifetime.

title.children: 'Feels like hatred': Meet the town that voted 'no' in the last Indigenous referendum

image.altText: Person sleeping face down.

items.synopsis: Non-Indigenous Australians are 18 per cent more likely to die due to extreme heat compared to Indigenous Australians, a study has found. The remedy is common sense, according to a Warumungu elder.

title.children: How taking a nap instead of cranking the aircon could help us survive 'killer' heat

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: The woman who hosted the lunch that police believe resulted in three people dying from mushroom poisoning has spoken of her anguish at the deaths and denied doing anything wrong.

title.children: 'I didn't do anything, I loved them': Cook of mushroom meal police suspect killed three people protests innocence

image.altText: a red Tesla Model 3 sedan is charged at a Tesla dealership with the Tesla logo shown on the dealership building in the back

items.synopsis: Tesla's chief financial officer, Zachary Kirkhorn, leaves the electric car-maker, and the ASX is higher after a rise on Wall Street ahead of the inflation report.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Elon Musk successor steps down from Tesla, ASX gains after Wall Street rally ahead of inflation report

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened higher after a rebound on Wall Street. The ASX 200 index has put on 0.3 per cent. Miners and banks have edged up, but most sectors are in the red so far including healthcare stocks. Spot gold fell on concerns of further interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve and iron ore prices dropped amid further cuts in steel production by China. Oil prices were also caught up in the selling after last week's highs on reduced supply. ASX 200 best and worst performers: James Hardie: +14.6% after seeing underlying profit grow over the first quarter. Lake Resources: +5.7% Domain: +2.6% Coronado Global Resources: -11.7% after net profit slumped by two-thirds for the half year to $199 million. Charter Hall: -3.5% Sayona Mining: -3.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher

children.content: The Australian share market has opened higher after a rebound on Wall Street.
The ASX 200 index has put on 0.3 per cent.
Miners and banks have edged up, but most sectors are in the red so far including healthcare stocks.
Spot gold fell on concerns of further interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve and iron ore prices dropped amid further cuts in steel production by China.
Oil prices were also caught up in the selling after last week's highs on reduced supply.
ASX 200 best and worst performers:
James Hardie: +14.6% after seeing underlying profit grow over the first quarter.
Lake Resources: +5.7%
Domain: +2.6%
Coronado Global Resources: -11.7% after net profit slumped by two-thirds for the half year to $199 million.
Charter Hall: -3.5%
Sayona Mining: -3.3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: For all your early birds out there, the tax office says you have the "green light" to lodge your tax return. Assistant ATO commissioner Tim Loh says most taxpayers with simple affairs will find the information they need to lodge has been pre-filled on their tax return. "Most of the information we collect from employers, banks, private health insurers, share registries, and other institutions is now ready to go." " So, if your financial affairs are fairly straight-forward, you’ve got a ‘green light’ to lodge — but remember you still need to check your details are accurate before you hit submit." Mr Loh says some information may need to be filled in manually such as income from rental properties, some government payments or income from side hustles. The ATO has 40 occupation guides for claiming deductions you are entitled to. ATO tax tips: Include all your income Assess your circumstances this year You must have a record to claim a work-related expense Wait for your notice of assessment Stay alert to scams The due date for payment is 21 November if you are lodging your own return.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ATO says time to lodge tax return but make sure it's accurate

children.content: For all your early birds out there, the tax office says you have the "green light" to lodge your tax return.
Assistant ATO commissioner Tim Loh
says most taxpayers with simple affairs will find the information they need to lodge has been pre-filled on their tax return.
"Most of the information we collect from employers, banks, private health insurers, share registries, and other institutions is now ready to go."
" So, if your financial affairs are fairly straight-forward, you’ve got a ‘green light’ to lodge — but remember you still need to check your details are accurate before you hit submit."
Mr Loh says some information may need to be filled in manually such as income from rental properties, some government payments or income from side hustles.
The ATO has 40 occupation guides for claiming deductions you are entitled to.
ATO tax tips:
Include all your income
Assess your circumstances this year
You must have a record to claim a work-related expense
Wait for your notice of assessment
Stay alert to scams
The due date for payment is
21 November
if you are lodging your own return.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Hardie has provided an interesting result early in the corporate reporting season. The Australian building materials producer, which is heavily focused on the US market, reported falling first quarter sales (-5% to $US954 million) but an increased underlying profit. The company's adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) jumped 12% to $US279 million. The reason? A massive growth in profit margins. The company's adjusted EBITDA margin jumped from 24.9 to 29.2% over the past year. Both the company's US and Asia-Pacific fiber cement divisions posted record EBIT profit margins of 31.1% and 33.1% respectively. Those margins jumped 5.4 percentage points in the US and 7.5 percentage points in the Asia-Pacific region since its first quarter results a year ago. Slumping volumes saw the company's European building products division report a decrease in earnings, with rising costs keeping margins stagnant despite a steep rise in prices. Overall, the company ended up reporting a small (-3%) fall in its statutory net profit, which came in at $US157.8 million ($240 million).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: James Hardie grows profits on prices and margins as volumes fall

children.content: James Hardie
has provided an interesting result early in the corporate reporting season.
The Australian building materials producer, which is heavily focused on the US market, reported
falling first quarter sales (-5% to $US954 million)
but an
increased underlying profit
The company's adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) jumped 12% to $US279 million.
The reason? A massive
growth in profit margins
The company's adjusted EBITDA margin jumped from 24.9 to 29.2% over the past year.
Both the company's US and Asia-Pacific fiber cement divisions posted
record EBIT profit margins
of 31.1% and 33.1% respectively.
Those margins jumped 5.4 percentage points in the US and 7.5 percentage points in the Asia-Pacific region since its first quarter results a year ago.
Slumping volumes saw the company's European building products division report a decrease in earnings, with rising costs keeping margins stagnant despite a steep rise in prices.
Overall, the company ended up reporting
a small (-3%) fall in its statutory net profit
, which came in at $US157.8 million ($240 million).
